sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Modern immigration systems serve as critical infrastructure for national security, economic development, and human mobility1–3. They are responsible for enforcing legal entry and residency requirements, managing customs and trade compliance, and facilitating humanitarian protections4,5. However, these systems face mounting pressure from cyber threats, regulatory complexity, and operational inefficiencies6,7. A 2023 breach of a European border agency exposed over 120,000 asylum application records, highlighting the vulnerability of centralized data repositories. In high-volume corridors like the US–Mexico border and the Schengen Area, visa approval times can exceed 30 days, resulting in economic losses of over €2.1 billion annually.

These challenges expose a fundamental design trilemma: no existing architecture achieves security, regulatory compliance, and operational efficiency at scale8–10. Centralized systems are vulnerable to single points of failure, while siloed communication across immigration, customs, and financial institutions increases the risk of identity fraud and delays11–13. Interpol reports a 22% annual rise in forged travel documents since 2020. Meanwhile, regulatory mandates such as the GDPR demand privacy-preserving solutions that legacy technologies are ill-equipped to deliver.

Blockchain technology has emerged as a potential enabler of secure, decentralized trust across borders14–16. Its core attributes-cryptographic integrity, auditability, and programmability-make it well-suited to applications that span multiple jurisdictions and stakeholders17. However, real-world deployments have revealed important limitations18. Public, permissionless blockchains such as Ethereum often conflict with regulatory frameworks, particularly the GDPR’s “right to erasure”19. Permissioned systems like vanilla Hyperledger Fabric provide better governance but lack Byzantine fault tolerance, becoming vulnerable when a third or more of the nodes act maliciously.

Several studies have proposed blockchain-based tools for specific immigration-related challenges. Shinde and Gurrala proposed a forensic data system using enhanced Blowfish encryption and IPFS-based decentralized logs, but scalability and detection accuracy declined with user growth. Visvizi et al. designed rWallet, a blockchain-based e-wallet and identity solution for irregular migrants, which used smart contracts and biometric authentication to support aid distribution. While promising, rWallet remains untested in real-world conditions. Similarly, Abraha emphasized blockchain’s role in improving transparency in refugee management, yet highlighted major barriers such as technology accessibility, privacy concerns, and stakeholder coordination.

Across 37 blockchain proposals reviewed for immigration use cases, three recurring limitations emerge: (1) the security-throughput tradeoff, where Byzantine fault-tolerant systems operate below 300 TPS, while high-throughput networks lack robust fault tolerance; (2) the privacy paradox, where zk-SNARKs preserve anonymity but introduce latency unsuitable for time-sensitive scenarios like customs inspection; and (3) the scalability gap, where integrating off-chain systems like IPFS creates interoperability friction with legacy government infrastructure. sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: The integration of blockchain technology into identity management, border control, and digital immigration systems has been extensively explored in recent research, demonstrating its potential to enhance security, transparency, and efficiency20–22. Various studies have proposed blockchain-based frameworks for self-sovereign identity (SSI), digital passports, permissioned networks, and consensus optimizations, addressing challenges such as fraud prevention, data privacy, and interoperability23–25. However, these approaches exhibit certain technical, regulatory, and scalability limitations, necessitating further advancements to establish a strong, real-world deployable system26,27.

Mirko Forti’s study explores blockchain’s role in migration-related identity management, highlighting its potential to improve transparency and empower migrants through secure, portable identities28. Using legal analysis, case studies (like the UNHCR’s Rohingya project), and frameworks such as Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI), the research identifies both benefits and risks. Key concerns include algorithmic bias, GDPR conflicts, and data immutability. Challenges such as infrastructure dependency and potential exclusion are noted. The study recommends private, permissioned blockchains with human oversight to ensure rights protection while fostering innovation.

Ishita Maheshkumar Thanki and others proposed a passport-based framework for secure, standardized identity verification and travel across different metaverses29. Their system uses centralized or distributed servers to authenticate digital citizens (avatars) and issue metaverse-specific visas. While it enhances security, accountability, and user rights, challenges include centralization (which may conflict with decentralization ideals), interoperability issues, scalability, privacy concerns, and the need for broad adoption to be effective.

Pradnya B. Patil and M. Sangeetha analyzed the performance of a Hyperledger Fabric blockchain for cross-border fund transfers using Hyperledger Caliper and a queuing theory model30. They assessed how block size, workload, and transaction rates affect latency and throughput, finding that latency generally increases with load but decreases after 20,000 transactions due to reduced overhead. However, their single-channel, solo-orderer setup and limited real-world testing may reduce the applicability of results to complex, real-world systems.

Youn-A Min introduced a modified Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (mpBFT) algorithm to improve efficiency in private blockchains by cutting communication costs and speeding up consensus31. Enhancements included streamlined request handling, a message priority status bit, and a Raft-inspired, reliability-based leader election. mpBFT demonstrated reduced node sacrifice (from 33.3% to 16.7%), lower communication costs, and improved TPS over traditional pBFT. However, the study assumed honest nodes, lacked real-world testing, and relied on subjective criteria for leader selection-raising concerns about scalability, potential bias, and resilience to malicious actors.

Zaynah Dargaye and others proposed a framework for secure, trusted-by-design smart contracts using Cyberlogic, a formal trust management system implemented in Coq32. They used it to specify and verify protocols like the Schengen visa process, ensuring accountability via formal proofs. Verified specifications can be compiled into executable smart contract code (e.g., Solidity or Michelson). Despite its strong theoretical foundation, the framework lacks runtime monitoring and real-world deployment, and its reliance on formal methods may pose accessibility challenges for developers unfamiliar with formal verification.

Keenu Chandra, Maroof Mushtaq, and Dr. Nalini N. developed a digital passport and visa management system using Hyperledger Fabric to enhance security and efficiency over traditional methods33. Their modular setup, with smart contracts and CouchDB, automates document issuance and verification while reducing fraud and improving access via a user-friendly web interface. However, reliance on a centralized orderer poses a single point of failure, scalability for large-scale deployment is untested, and the system assumes trust among all participating entities-an assumption that may not hold in real-world applications.

Rishabh Garg conducted a survey on using zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) with blockchain to improve privacy in identity-sharing systems34. The study compared protocols like zk-SNARKs and zk-STARKs, emphasizing their ability to verify identities securely without exposing personal data. It also reviewed real-world applications and outlined the potential of ZKPs and blockchain to overcome flaws in centralized identity models. However, challenges remain in scalability, usability, regulation, and the technical complexity of ZKP implementation, which limits broader adoption and highlights the need for further standardization and optimization.

Lu Zhou and others surveyed the use of zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) in blockchain-based identity sharing, emphasizing their role in enhancing privacy and trustless verification35. By analyzing techniques like zk-SNARKs and zk-STARKs, along with real-world case studies, the study highlighted benefits such as improved privacy, security, and interoperability in decentralized systems. However, it also pointed out challenges, including scalability limitations, high computational costs, and implementation complexity. The authors advocate for further research to overcome these barriers and support wider adoption of ZKP-enabled identity solutions.

Qiwei Hu and others introduced PDPB, a blockchain system tailored for decentralized Policy Decision Point (PDP) functions in Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)36. Using a novel Echo-Based Execution Conclude (EBEC) mechanism and optimizations like Echo Compacting and Load Balancing, they reduced system overhead and boosted throughput by 35.6%–59.8% in AWS-based tests. Despite these gains, the system increases communication complexity and assumes sufficient memory for storing all policies-an assumption that may not hold in constrained environments, potentially limiting its broader applicability.

Our research synthesizes these diverse approaches into a unified framework that addresses four persistent limitations in the field. First, where Forti’s SSI model and Thanki’s metaverse system struggled with regulatory compliance, our architecture embeds GDPR principles through selective disclosure mechanisms and cryptographic right-to-erasure - enabling data minimization while maintaining necessary audit trails. Second, unlike Patil’s idealized simulations or Min’s honest-node assumption, we validate performance in production-like environments, demonstrating consistent 1,200 TPS throughput even with 15% Byzantine nodes. Third, we transcend the trade-off between Dargaye’s formal verification and Chandra’s practical implementation by developing a two-layer smart contract system: core logic verified in Coq (inspired by Cyberlogic) wrapped in runtime-monitored business logic. Finally, we solve Zhou’s scalability challenge through our novel “proof cascading” technique, where zk-SNARKs for frequent operations (document checks) reference less frequent zk-STARK proofs (identity verification), reducing average proof generation overhead by 63% compared to pure zk-SNARK implementations. This integrated approach not only overcomes individual limitations but creates emergent properties - such as our system’s ability to process 20,000+ concurrent applications without the performance degradation observed in Shindep’s model17. Table 2 synthesizes key differences between prior works and our proposed system.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: Chapter 3 presents a hierarchical framework for blockchain-based immigration management, where subsections follow a workflow from system architecture to real-world validation. “Overview of the peer nodes” section introduces the node roles and PBFT consensus, forming the foundation for secure transactions. “Connecting web application with hyperledger fabric” and “Identity and document management” sections detail document and financial workflows, which rely on the node architecture. “Financial integration layer” and “Customs and security monitoring” sections address customs and tax compliance, leveraging the verified data from earlier stages. Finally, “Tax compliance monitoring”, “Application and integration layer”, “Authority access and verification”, “Security and privacy layer” sections ensure system integrity through authority access controls, anomaly detection, and smart contract deployment. This structure mirrors the operational lifecycle of immigration processes: from submission (3.2) to verification (3.3), compliance (3.4–3.5), and auditing (3.6–3.9).

sec.title: Overview of the peer nodes
PBFT-enhanced request processing in hyperledger fabric
sec.p: In standard Hyperledger Fabric, consensus is typically achieved using Raft or Kafka, which provide crash fault tolerance (CFT). However, our framework enhances this by integrating Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) to address Byzantine faults. This substitution significantly improves resilience against malicious or arbitrary node behaviors.
Prepare: Each node validates the transaction’s signature, structure, and compliance with defined policies, then multicasts its prepare vote to other nodes.

Despite the use of PBFT, our architecture maintains Fabric’s unique execute-order-validate model. In the execute phase, each node simulates the transaction against the current ledger state, including privacy and compliance checks such as GDPR enforcement using zk-SNARKs. In the order phase, PBFT replaces Raft as the ordering mechanism, finalizing the transaction sequence. The validate phase involves additional custom verifications, such as Merkle proof checks for document hash integrity, before committing the transaction to the ledger.

sec.title: Connecting web application with hyperledger fabric
sec.p: The integration of event listeners enhances system responsiveness. These listeners capture blockchain updates and notify users about application status changes. The final system ensures the secure submission, validation, approval, and tracking of applications, guaranteeing data integrity and transparency while providing users with verifiable blockchain-based documents.

sec.title: Identity and document management
sec.p: At the core of the proposed system is a blockchain network that securely manages user identities and documents. When users submit documents, they undergo encryption, hashing, and storage on the blockchain to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and immutability. Smart contracts govern the processes of user registration, document verification, and timestamping, thereby providing tamper-resistance and traceability.

By employing blockchain-based verification and cryptographic hashing, the system ensures document integrity while preventing tampering or fraudulent submissions. The verification process enhances transparency, strengthens security, and provides immutable proof of document authenticity.

This document update procedure ensures confidentiality and authenticity using encryption and hashing, while blockchain immutability guarantees transparency and data integrity. By maintaining references to previous document versions, the system fosters a robust and auditable document management framework essential for secure immigration processes.Fig. 2
Document lifecycle workflow showing cryptographic processing, blockchain submission, and verification.

sec.title: Financial integration layer
Customs and security monitoring
sec.p: Customs officials keep an eye on the goods that immigrants are carrying using a specialized interface that is linked to the blockchain network. The blockchain records customs information and associates it with people’s profiles. Any illegal materials or smuggling incidents are promptly noted and reported. This layer stops illegal activity and improves border security.
This structured procedure ensures systematic inspection, regulatory compliance, and immutable blockchain-based record-keeping.

Immigration and customs officials can make well-informed choices regarding the entry of immigrants and implement extra checks and measures as needed by adhering to this thorough risk assessment procedure. The algorithm offers a strong foundation for managing high-risk instances while guaranteeing that risk assessments are transparent and consistent.

sec.title: Tax compliance monitoring
sec.p: Our suggested system’s “Tax Compliance Monitoring” process represents our steadfast dedication to openness and legal compliance. This technique gives users and authorities real-time insights into fiscal duties by closely monitoring and evaluating tax compliance. In addition to offering procedures for resolving inconsistencies and guaranteeing equity in tax assessments, it promotes a culture of tax compliance. This all-encompassing strategy enhances our platform’s general dependability and trustworthiness.

sec.title: Application and integration layer
sec.p: To ensure seamless migration of existing passport and visa records into the blockchain system, a structured integration approach is adopted. This involves unique identifier mapping, API-based data transfers, and blockchain-based validation.

sec.title: Authority access and verification
sec.p: The Authority Access and Verification system ensures secure access to passport and visa information for authorized personnel. The system employs biometric authentication, cryptographic verification, and blockchain-based logging to maintain data accuracy, prevent unauthorized access, and ensure a transparent, auditable access trail.

sec.title: Security and privacy layer
sec.p: Blockchain technology uses consensus processes and encryption to protect data. By using cryptographic keys, only authorized workers can access sensitive data. The highest levels of security and privacy are maintained by using private and public keys to secure transactions and authenticate users.

sec.title: Data encryption and decryption
Anomaly detection for unauthorized access
Blockchain infrastructure
sec.p: Transaction Validation and Commitment: The Transaction Validation and Commitment process is fundamental to ensuring the integrity, security, and reliability of transactions within a Hyperledger Fabric blockchain network. The lack of a secure and decentralized data management framework presents significant challenges in immigration management. Our approach leverages a blockchain-based solution with the Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) consensus algorithm, ensuring robust data integrity, decentralization, and trust among multiple stakeholders.

The Transaction Validation and Commitment process ensures rigorous verification, cryptographic security, and network-wide consensus, protecting the blockchain ledger against unauthorized modifications. Any anomalies encountered during the process are documented for auditing, facilitating real-time troubleshooting and maintaining blockchain reliability.Fig. 4
PBFT consensus mechanism.

This activity diagram in Fig. 4 represents the workflow of the Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) consensus mechanism, which is used to achieve agreement in a distributed system, even in the presence of faulty or malicious nodes. The process begins with the client sending a request to the Primary node, which then broadcasts the request to all Backup nodes in the system. Each Backup node receives the request and sends a Pre-Prepare message to all nodes, which is then checked for validity. If the Pre-Prepare message is valid, the Backup nodes proceed by sending a Prepare message to all other nodes. A decision point is introduced here, where the Backup nodes check if the majority of nodes have sent their Prepare votes. If a sufficient number of votes are received, the nodes send a Commit message to all nodes; otherwise, they wait for more votes. Once the nodes receive Commit messages, they again check if a majority of Commit votes are received. If the majority is met, they send the final Reply to the client, signaling that the consensus has been reached. If the majority is not reached at any stage, the nodes discard the current message and wait for more votes. This diagram captures the sequential steps and decision points of the PBFT protocol, emphasizing the importance of majority agreement at various stages to ensure the integrity and reliability of the system, even in the presence of faulty or malicious nodes.

Smart Contract Deployment: The Smart Contract Deployment process facilitates the execution of self-executing agreements within a blockchain network, enabling secure, automated transactions based on predefined conditions. The Hyperledger Fabric framework leverages a modular smart contract system, referred to as chaincode, to govern decentralized execution.

An essential component of blockchain infrastructure is the Smart Contract Deployment procedure, which guarantees the safe, law-abiding, and consensus-driven implementation of self-executing contracts. Using network-wide configuration updates, endorsement policies, and cryptographic verification, the process guarantees thorough validation at every level. Effective debugging and maintenance are made possible by the thorough documentation of any anomalies or problems that occur during deployment.

sec.title: Result analysis
sec.p: The proposed blockchain-based immigration system was thoroughly evaluated through a three-phase validation process: (1) controlled laboratory benchmarks measuring cryptographic operations and consensus performance, (2) a 90-day pilot deployment at two European border checkpoints processing actual visa applications, and (3) stress testing under simulated peak loads equivalent to major international airports. This multi-modal assessment strategy ensures both technical robustness and operational viability, addressing a critical gap in prior works that relied solely on synthetic datasets or limited test environments. Our hybrid evaluation framework combines quantitative metrics (throughput, latency, resource utilization) with qualitative assessments from border control officers and immigration applicants, providing comprehensive insights into real-world applicability.

sec.p: The evaluation environment comprised both physical and virtualized components to simulate real-world immigration ecosystems:

Regarding the data sources, real immigration records from the Schengen Visa Information System (1.2 million anonymized documents) are used, along with synthetic financial transactions generated through the FATF Typology Engine.

Three operational modes were evaluated in the system. The first mode, Baseline Mode, represents standard processing without any anomalies. In this mode, only document verification is performed, with a fixed transaction value of 0.1 ETH.

The second mode, Stress Mode, simulates adversarial conditions. This mode involves 15% Byzantine nodes that inject invalid transactions, network partitions introducing 50-200ms of artificial latency, and 5% malicious documents, such as forged passports.
The third mode, Compliance Mode, ensures adherence to regulatory requirements. In this mode, FATF Rule 16 is enforced, alongside GDPR right-to-erasure requests.

sec.title: Node representation in real-world deployment
sec.p: This node distribution mirrors the operational ratios observed in actual EU border checkpoint operations, where financial intermediaries tend to outnumber other participants due to the stringent requirements of anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorism financing (CTF) regulations. The chosen node counts were further validated through interviews conducted with representatives from three European immigration agencies during the pilot planning phase.

sec.title: Pilot site configuration and data validation
sec.p: The pilot deployment was carried out at two high-traffic locations Frankfurt Airport in Germany and Rotterdam Port in the Netherlands chosen due to their high volumes of visa applications. At each site, 16 physical servers were deployed on-premises, comprising four government, six financial, four customs, and two integration nodes. Over the course of the pilot, a total of 23,541 anonymized visa applications were processed; these were real submissions with all personally identifiable information removed to ensure privacy. To validate the system’s accuracy, border officers manually reviewed 5% of the transactions, amounting to 1,177 cases, to confirm the correctness of automated decisions.

sec.title: CPU utilization analysis
Comparison with related works
sec.p:
The comparative analysis in Table 9 demonstrates our system’s superiority across all performance metrics. While existing solutions either compromise on decentralization (Shindep’s PoA) or efficiency (Abraha’s PoW), our optimized PBFT achieves an unprecedented balance - consuming 79% less energy than the closest competitor (Visviizi) while delivering 5.4× faster transaction finality. The hardware-agnostic design reduces infrastructure costs by 62% compared to GPU-dependent approaches, and our Hyperledger 2.5+ modifications enable sustained throughput at 1/3 the energy cost of standard Fabric 2.x implementations. Notably, only our solution simultaneously meets the trifecta of immigration system requirements: enterprise-grade consensus (Byzantine fault tolerance), regulatory-compliant privacy (zk-SNARKs), and real-time performance (<50ms latency). This comparative advantage stems from our novel batching techniques that reduce cryptographic operations by 37% and our dynamic resource governor that cuts idle energy waste by 43%.Table 9

sec.title: Security analysis
Conclusion
sec.p: Future recommendations focus on advancing the system by transitioning to post-quantum cryptography to ensure security as quantum computing evolves, integrating federated learning for better fraud detection and privacy, and establishing interoperability standards for secure visa-status sharing across borders. Additionally, adopting proof-of-stake for non-critical blockchain operations could significantly reduce the carbon footprint.
